issue.title: Scaffold Main Documentation using asciidoc
issue.body:
***Note**: This issue was originally created as [ARROW-95](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-95). Please see the [migration documentation](https://gist.github.com/toddfarmer/12aa88361532d21902818a6044fda4c3) for further details.*

### Original Issue Description:
For the general documentation of Arrow, we want to use asciidoc. The "general documentation" includes:
 \* The Arrow spec / memory layout
 \* Howtos for building arrow on different platforms
 \* Getting Started snippets for each language and a link to the (to-be-build) API documentation

It would be nice to have a build system and the main file/folder structure in place so we can split the work up.

comments.body:
***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-95?focusedCommentId=15226473) by Jacques Nadeau (jnadeau):*
I didn't see a conversation about why asciidoc versus Markdown. Did I miss the discussion? We've been using Markdown on Drill and Calcite with reasonable success.

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-95?focusedCommentId=15226520) by Uwe Korn (uwe):*
There was no real discussion why asciidoc versus Markdown. `[~wesmckinn]` suggested it and there were no objections. Probably we should raise that on the ML? At least a mail with the rough idea of how the documentation should be structured?

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-95?focusedCommentId=15226556) by Wes McKinney (wesm):*
We chatted briefly about it on Slack – I presumed we'd have a ML discussion or a high level JIRA about making a technical decision, so let's do that. 

I'm trying to find the Drill or Calcite documentation sources, can someone send a link to those to me? 

My understanding is that Markdown is much more minimal than reStructuredText or Asciidoc for creating more complex / interconnected documentation. As an example of this, named anchors don't really work in Markdown (http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6695439/how-do-you-create-link-to-a-named-anchor-in-multimarkdown), and solutions for them are HTML-specific. What if we want to generate a PDF? Maybe this need is hard to anticipate, but I'm not very comfortable using Markdown for more than READMEs and blogs (e.g. Jekyll / Pelican). 

Folks with more Markdown experience making more complex documentation should comment on their experience and how much Markdown's limitations (as compared with rst / adoc) end up being problems.

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-95?focusedCommentId=15226560) by Wes McKinney (wesm):*
See an example of a Sphinx-generated PDF: http://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/version/0.18.0/pandas.pdf. Setting aside the fact that the release notes is 250 pages, in my experience people do like having PDF versions of things.

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-95?focusedCommentId=15981776) by Wes McKinney (wesm):*
Issue resolved by pull request 589
